description:
Citreimonas salinaria is a species of haloarchaea, a group of microorganisms that belong to the domain Archaea. Haloarchaea are known for their ability to thrive in high-salt environments, such as hypersaline lakes and evaporation ponds.

Citreimonas salinaria is a Gram-negative, non-motile, and pleomorphic (capable of assuming various cell shapes) archaeon. It is capable of heterotrophic growth, meaning it can utilize organic compounds as its carbon and energy sources. The cells of C. salinaria are typically orange-pigmented, due to the presence of carotenoid pigments, which help protect the organism from the damaging effects of ultraviolet radiation in its high-salt habitat.

This species was first isolated from a hypersaline environment in China and is known to be able to grow in media containing up to 25% (w/v) sodium chloride. It is considered a halophilic (salt-loving) organism, as it requires the presence of high concentrations of salt for optimal growth and survival.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Citreimonas salinaria belongs to the family Halobacteriaceae within the Euryarchaeota phylum of the Archaea domain. Further research on the physiology, ecology, and genomic characteristics of this species can provide insights into the adaptations of haloarchaea to extreme saline environments.
